awd_titl_txt: NSF/DMR-BSF: Quantum Transport in a Helical One-Dimensional System
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract: 
The invention of the silicon transistor and decades of research development by academia and industry led to the current era of rapid information processing and propagation characterized by computers and the internet. The silicon transistor is rapidly approaching its limit of performance. To go beyond the conventional silicon technology requires drastically different paradigms that are fundamentally quantum in nature and operate on new materials and device concepts that are yet to be discovered. Quantum wires that can carry current without dissipating energy and transport information-carrying quantum states without losing coherence are an important building block of the next-generation quantum computers and quantum networks. In prior research, the PI's lab discovered a new type of quantum wire that has the above potential. The objectives of this project are to further understand the fundamental properties of the wires and develop its technological potential by constructing nanoscale devices and performing measurements in such systems. Knowledge gained in this research is expected to have significant impact on the development of quantum electronics. The research activities aim to educate the next-generation workforce of quantum technologies.  

Technical abstract: 
The PI's lab recently pioneered a new one-dimensional helical system in bilayer graphene known as the kink states, where the valley degrees of freedom of an electron is locked to its direction of propagation. Electrons moving in opposite directions carry opposite valley indices. The valley-momentum locked quantum wires display excellent ballistic transport properties and support the operations of a topological valley valve, a waveguide and a tunable electron beam splitter, which the PI's lab demonstrated. This project seeks to further develop capabilities to manipulate and probe interactions of the kink states beyond conductance measurements. The research activities aim to construct a quantum point contact and utilize the versatile tunability of the platform to systematically examine the controlled coupling of the kink states at the quantum point contact, in particular signatures of interacting one-dimensional systems. The construction of a Mach-Zehnder interferometer enables the studies of phase coherence transport of the kink states. Research efforts also include coupling the kink states to a high upper-critical-field superconductor through superconductor-kink-superconductor junctions and understanding the supercurrent distribution carried by the kink states. These experiments lay the foundation of pursuing emergent phenomena in superconductor-kink hybrid structures. Experiments are aided by theoretical efforts in the interpretation and prediction of measurements. Experimental and theoretical knowledge obtained in this project fundamentally enrich the understandings of topology, superconductivity and one-dimensional physics. The research activities equip students of all levels with necessary skills to pursue careers in STEM fields and summer camp activities promote science leadership among high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported experiments aimed at understanding electronics transport phenomena in two-dimensional materials, where the electron-electron interaction plays an important role and a special type of quantum wires called edge states offers a potential quantum information highway. Both efforts seek to advance the fundamental understanding of quantum mechanics in low dimensions, with potential applications in quantum information science. High sample quality and sophisticated nanolithography are crucial to the success of these explorations. This project supported the development of new fabrication methods that led to ultra-clean bilayer graphene devices. We observed a new even-denominator fractional quantum Hall state, as well as the appearance of the so-called Levin-Halperin daughter states of the Moore-Read Pfaffian or anti-Pfaffian, which are two distinct topological orders. These observations suggest that the particle-hole symmetry at even-denominator fractional quantum Hall states in bilayer graphene is explicitly broken. The electrically tuned valley isospin degrees of freedom is found to behave like an SU(2) spinor. The tuning of valley and orbital degrees of freedom creates a coincidence between two Landau levels of opposite valleys and different Landau level orbitals. Our measurements reveal a new type of fractional quantum Hall states forming precisely at this coincidence point, which is suspected to be a two-component state. This unusual two-component wave function enriches the physics of the fractional quantum Hall effect. Motivated by the prospect of creating electron quantum optics elements that are potentially useful in quantum information transport, we have further advanced the science and technology of the kink states, which are the edge states of the quantum valley Hall effect in bilayer graphene. Incorporating a graphite backgate into our third-generation devices, we demonstrated robust conductance quantization of the kink states at zero magnetic field and up to at least 50 K in temperature. This result is a significant milestone in the studies of helical edge states and paves the path to future efforts of using the kink states as ballistic waveguides, switches and beam splitters to transmit quantum information in an all solid-state setup. The results obtained in these explorations are broadly disseminated to researchers of the filed through numerous journal publications, conference presentations and lectures at universities given by the PI and her students. 

This project supported the PhD dissertation of one graduate student and the training of two others in different stages of their studies. Working on the projects enabled them to acquire knowledge and skills broadly applicable to semiconductor physics and industry and quantum science and technology. The student who received major support from this project will graduate soon and pursue an academic career. This project also supported the research of one postdoc scholar, who has moved on to a faculty position. This project also supported the work of several undergraduate students at Penn State and from other institutions, who have gained valuable hands-on experiences in the lab and a broad perspective of frontier condensed matter and quantum materials research. Some have joined the workforce while others decided to continue their education by going to graduate schools. This project was carried out during the COVID pandemic. Graduate students developed do-it-at-home lab materials, instructions and video tutorials to guide the science experiments of middle-schoolers from the region. The PI leveraged her expertise to actively encourage K-12 students, especially young women, to pursue a career in STEM fields and facilitated the growth of research capacity at minority-serving colleges through panels and workshops.
